sen.j: 側室理真院、越智氏
sen.e: Rishinin, Concubine from Ochi clan.
Rishinin, Concubine from Ochi clan.
Rishinin, Concubine from Ochi clan.

sen.j: 徳川 頼宣（とくがわ よりのぶ）は、徳川家康の十男で、常陸国水戸藩、駿河国駿府藩、紀伊国紀州藩の藩主を歴任して紀州徳川家の祖となる。
sen.e: Yorinobu TOKUGAWA was the 10th son of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, and became a founder for Kishu Tokugawa Family after continuously serving as the lord of domain in the Domain of Mito, Hitachi-no-kuni, the Domain of Sumpu, Suruga-no-kuni and the Domain of Kishu, Ki-no-kuni.

Yorinobu TOKUGAWA was the 10th son of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, and became a founder of the Kishu Tokugawa Family after continuously serving as the lord of the Domain of Mito, Hitachi-no-kuni, the Domain of Sumpu, Suruga-no-kuni and the Domain of Kishu, Ki-no-kuni.

Yorinobu TOKUGAWA was the 10th son of Ieyasu TOKUGAWA, and became a founder of the Kishu Tokugawa family after continuously serving as the lord of the Domain of Mito, Hitachi Province, the Domain of Sunpu, Suruga Province and the Domain of Kishu, Ki Province.

sen.j: 母は側室の養珠院（お万の方）である。
sen.e: His mother was Yojuin (Oman-no-kata) as a concubine.
His mother was named Yojuin (Oman-no-kata) and she was a concubine.
His mother was named Yojuin (Oman-no-kata) and she was a concubine.

sen.j: 八代将軍徳川吉宗の祖父にあたる。
sen.e: He was a grandfather of the 8th Shogun Yoshimune TOKUGAWA.
He was grandfather to the 8th Shogun Yoshimune TOKUGAWA.
He was grandfather to the 8th Shogun Yoshimune TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 幼名は長福丸、元服に伴い頼将、元和 (日本)年中に頼信さらに頼宣と改名する。
sen.e: His childhood name was Chofuku-maru ship, and he changed his name to Yorimasa due to the Ｃoming-age-ceremony, and Yorinobu (頼信) and Yorinobu (頼宣) between 1615 and 1624.
His childhood name was Chofuku-maru, but with his coming-of-age ceremony he changed his name to Yorimasa; and later to Yorinobu (頼信) and then Yorinobu (頼宣) between 1615 and 1624.
sen.cmt: wording; I don't understand why the term 'ship' is being used here. Why not just stick with Chofuku-maru? Also, 元服 is more naturally translated into 'Coming-of-age ceremony'.
sen.e: His childhood name was Chofuku-maru, but with his coming-of-age ceremony he changed his name to Yorimasa; and later to Yorinobu (頼信) and then Yorinobu (頼宣) between 1615 and 1624.

tit.cmt: 用語統一リストによる

sen.j: 1606年（慶長11年）、家康に従い京都に上り元服。
sen.e: In 1606, he went to Kyoto squiring Ieyasu and held the coming-age-ceremony.
In 1606, he had his coming-of-age ceremony in Kyoto when he travelled there to serve Ieyasu.
In 1606, he had his coming-of-age ceremony in Kyoto when he travelled there following Ieyasu.
sen.cmt: 家康に従い→following Ieyasu としました

sen.j: 1617年2月27日（元和 (日本)3年正月22日）に加藤清正の第五女・八十姫（瑤林院）を正室とする。
sen.e: On February 27, 1617, he got married with the 5th daughter of Kiyomasa KATO, Yasohime (Yorinin) as a legal wife.
On February 27, 1617, he took the 5th daughter of Kiyomasa KATO, Yasohime (Yorinin), as his legal wife.
On February 27, 1617, he took the 5th daughter of Kiyomasa KATO, Yasohime (Yorinin), as his legal wife.

sen.j: 1619年（元和5年）、紀伊国紀州藩55万5千石に転封、紀州徳川家の家祖となる。
sen.e: In 1619, his territory was changed to the 555 thousand goku Domain of Kishu, Ki-no-kuni, and he became a founder for Kishu Tokugawa Family.
In 1619, his territory was changed to the 555 thousand goku Domain of Kishu, Ki-no-kuni, and he became a founder of the Kishu Tokugawa Family.
In 1619, his territory was changed to the 555 thousand koku Domain of Kishu, Ki Province, and he became a founder of the Kishu Tokugawa family.

sen.j: 入国の前に、家臣を派遣して、以前の領主・浅野氏に対する領民の不満などを調査させている。
sen.e: Before his entry to Ki-no-kuni, he had conducted a research about residents' complaints against former feudal lord Asano clan through his followers sent.
Prior to entering Ki-no-kuni, he sent his followers to investigate complaints from residents about the former feudal lord and Asano clan.
Prior to entering Ki Province, he sent his followers to investigate complaints from residents about the Asano clan, the former feudal lord.
sen.cmt: no-kuni→Province原文の意に沿うよう、最後の部分を修正。

sen.j: 入国後は、和歌山城の改築、城下町の整備など、紀州藩の繁栄の基礎を築いた。
sen.e: After his entry, he constructed the foundation for the Domain of Kishu to enjoy prosperity, such as the renovation of Wakayama Castle, the establishment of the castle towns, etc.
After entering Ki-no-kuni he laid the foundation for the subsequent prosperity of Kishu Domain by renovating Wakayama Castle, establishing castle towns etc.
After entering Ki Province he laid the foundation for the subsequent prosperity of Kishu Domain by renovating Wakayama Castle, establishing castle towns etc.

sen.j: また、地元の国人を懐柔する地士制度を実施した。
sen.e: He, also, introduced the Jizamurai (upper-rank in rural community) system to propitiate local people.
He, also introduced the Jizamurai (upper-rank in rural community) system to appease local people.
He, also introduced the Jizamurai (upper-rank samurai in rural community) system to appease local people.

sen.j: また、浪人問題を解消すべく、多くの対策を打ち出した。
sen.e: He launched a lot of measures to resolve the problems of masterless samurai.
He launched numerous measures to resolve the problems of masterless samurai.
He launched numerous measures to resolve the problems of masterless samurai.

sen.j: 1651年（慶安4年）の慶安の変において、由井正雪が頼宣の印章文書を偽造していたため幕府に謀反の疑いをかけられ、10年間紀州へ帰国できなかった。
sen.e: In the Keian no Hen (Conspiracy of Keian) in 1651, he was suspected of plotting a rebellion by the Shogunate because Shosetsu YUI had forged Yorinobu's sealed papers, and couldn't return to Kishu for 10 years.

In the 1651 Keian no Hen (Conspiracy of Keian), the Shogunate suspected him of plotting a rebellion because Shosetsu YUI had forged Yorinobu's sealed papers, and he couldn't return to Kishu for 10 years.

In the 1651 Keian no Hen (Conspiracy of Keian), the Shogunate suspected him of plotting a rebellion because Shosetsu YUI had forged Yorinobu's sealed papers, and he couldn't return to Kishu for 10 years.

sen.j: なおその時期、明の遺臣・鄭成功（国姓爺）から日本に援軍要請があったが、頼宣はこれに応じることに積極的であったともいう。
sen.e: Meanwhile, in this period, surviving retainer Seiko TEI (Zheng Chenggong) (Kokusenya) in Ming asked Japan to dispatch reinforcements and Yorinobu seemed to be positive about corresponding to his request.
Meanwhile, in this period, a surviving retainer Seiko TEI (Zheng Chenggong) (Kokusenya) in Ming asked Japan to send reinforcements. Yorinobu reacted positively to this request.
Meanwhile, in this period, a surviving retainer Seiko TEI (Zheng Chenggong) (Kokusenya) in Ming asked Japan to send reinforcements, and Yorinobu reacted positively to this request.

sen.j: その後、疑いは晴れて無事帰国したが、和歌山城の増築を中止しなければならなかったとも言われる（和歌山県和歌山市にはこの伝承に因む堀止という地名がある）。
sen.e: Later, he was cleared of suspicion and safely back at home, but he seemed to be forced to stop extensions to Wakayama Castle (there is a place called Horidome based on this tradition in Wakayama City, Wakayama Prefecture.)

Later, he was cleared of all suspicion and returned safely to his home; however, he was apparently forced to cease extensions to Wakayama Castle (there is a place called Horidome based on this tradition in Wakayama City, Wakayama Prefecture).

Later, he was cleared of all suspicion and returned safely to his home; however, he was apparently forced to cease extensions to Wakayama Castle (there is a place called Horidome based on this tradition in Wakayama City, Wakayama Prefecture).

sen.j: 1667年（寛文7年）嫡男・徳川光貞に跡を譲り隠居。
sen.e: In 1667, he yielded his position to his legitimate son Mitsusada TOKUGAWA, and went into retirement.
In 1667, he yielded his position to his legitimate son Mitsusada TOKUGAWA, and went into retirement.
In 1667, he yielded his position to his legitimate son Mitsusada TOKUGAWA, and went into retirement.

sen.j: 覇気に富む人柄であったと伝えられている。
sen.e: He seemed to be a person full of ambitions.
He seemed to be a person full of ambition.
He seemed to be a person full of ambition.

tit.e: Chronology of Government Posts and Ranks
Chronology of Government Posts and Ranks
Chronology of Government Posts and Ranks

sen.j: ※日付は明治5年12月2日までは旧暦
sen.e: * Lunar calendar used for the dates on and before December 2, 1872.
* Lunar calendar used for the dates on and before December 2, 1872.
* Lunar calendar used for the dates on and before December 2, 1872.

sen.j: 1603年（慶長8年）11月7日 - 常陸国水戸20万石藩主として知行。
sen.e: November 7, 1603, running Chigyo fief for the 200 thousand goku Domain of Mito, Hitachi-no-kuni as a lord of domain.
On November 7, 1603, he was the lord of the 200 thousand goku Domain of Mito, Hitachi-no-kuni and ran the Chigyo fief.
On November 7, 1603, he was the lord of the 200 thousand koku Domain of Mito, Hitachi Province and ran the Chigyo fief.

sen.j: 1604年（慶長9年）9月 - 5万石を加増。
sen.e: September 1604, 50,000 goku added.
In September 1604, he added 50,000 goku.
In September 1604, 50,000 koku was increased.
sen.cmt: 原文の内容に合わせて修正。goku→koku

sen.j: 1606年（慶長11年）8月11日 - 元服し、頼将を名乗る。
sen.e: August 11, 1606, coming-age-ceremony and identified himself as Yorimasa.
On August 11, 1606, he had his coming-of-age ceremony and identified himself as Yorimasa.
On August 11, 1606, he had his coming-of-age ceremony and identified himself as Yorimasa.

sen.j: 従四位下常陸介に叙任。
sen.e: assuming the Jushii-no-ge rank, Hitachi no suke (vice governor of Hitachi-no-kuni.)
He assumed the rank of Jushii-no-ge, Hitachi no suke (vice governor of Hitachi-no-kuni).
He assumed the rank of Jushiinoge (Junior Fourth Rank, Lower Grade), Hitachi no suke (vice governor of Hitachi Province).

sen.j: 1609年（慶長14年）12月12日 - 駿河･遠江両国50万石に転封。
sen.e: December 12, 1609, his territory changed to the 500 thousand goku Suruga-no-kuni and Toe-no-kuni.
On December 12, 1609, his territory changed to the 500 thousand goku Suruga-no-kuni and Toe-no-kuni.
On December 12, 1609, his territory changed to the 500 thousand koku Provinces of Suruga and Totomi.

sen.j: 居城は駿河国駿府城。
sen.e: Kyojo Castle where he as the lord usually lived was Suruga-no-kuni Sumpu Castle.
Kyojo Castle, where the lord usually lived, was called Suruga-no-kuni Sumpu Castle.
He lived in Sunpu Castle in Suruga Province.
sen.cmt: 原文の内容に合わせて修正

sen.j: 1611年（慶長16年）3月20日 - 従三位参議左近衛権中将に昇叙転任。
sen.e: March 20, 1611, promoted to the Jusammi rank councilor Sakonoe-Gonchujo (supernumerary lieutenant general of Sakon-e-fu.)
On March 20, 1611, he was promoted to the rank of Jusanmmi councilor Sakonoe-Gonchujo (supernumerary lieutenant general of Sakon-e-fu).
On March 20, 1611, he was promoted to Jusanmi(Junior Third Rank) councilor Sakonoe-Gonchujo (supernumerary lieutenant general of Sakon-e-fu).

sen.j: その後、年月日不詳にて参議辞職。
sen.e: Later, the date unknown, resigned as councilor.
Later, he resigned as councillor on an unknown date.
Later, he resigned as councillor on an unknown date.

sen.j: 1617年（元和 (日本)3年）
sen.cmt: Not sure of the context of this; however, there is no indication in the Japanese that there should be an 'In' before the year.

sen.j: 7月19日 - 権中納言に転任。
sen.e: July 19, promoted to the supernumerary second-ranked councilor of state.
On July 19, he was promoted to the position of supernumerary second-ranked councilor of state.
On July 19, he was transferred to the position of Gon-Chunagon (supernumerary vice-councilor of state)
sen.cmt: 転任→transferredGon-Chunagonを補う位階名の英訳を修正

sen.j: 7月21日 - 権中納言辞任。
sen.e: July 21, resigned as supernumerary second-ranked councilor of state.
On July 21, he resigned from the position of supernumerary second-ranked councilor of state.
On July 21, he resigned from the position of Gon-Chunagon.
sen.cmt: 既出のため、権中納言の英訳を省く

sen.j: 1619年（元和5年）7月19日 - 紀伊国55万石余の藩主として転封。
sen.e: July 19, 1619, became a lord of domain of about 550 thousand goku Ki-no-kuni.
On July 19, 1619, he became the lord of the Ki-no-kuni domain with approximately 550 thousand goku.
On July 19, 1619, he became the lord of Ki Province with approximately 550 thousand koku.

sen.j: 1626年（寛永3年）8月19日 - 従二位権大納言に昇叙転任。
sen.e: August 19, 1626, promoted to the Junii rank supernumerary chief councilor of state
On August 19, 1626, he was promoted to the Junii rank of supernumerary chief councilor of state.
On August 19, 1626, he was promoted to Junii (Junior Second Rank) Dainagon.
sen.cmt: 既出のため、権中納言の英訳を省く位階名の英訳を補う

sen.j: 1667年（寛文7年）5月22日 - 隠居。
sen.e: May 22, 1667, went into retirement.
On May 22, 1667, he went into retirement.
On May 22, 1667, he went into retirement.
January 10, 1671, died.
He died on January 10, 1671.
He died on January 10, 1671.

sen.j: 墓所：和歌山県海南市の慶徳山長保寺 (海南市)
sen.e: Grave located at Choho-ji Temple, Keitoku-san in Kainan City, Wakayama Prefecture.
His grave is located in Choho-ji Temple, Keitoku-san in Kainan City, Wakayama Prefecture.
His grave is located in Choho-ji Temple, Keitoku-san in Kainan City, Wakayama Prefecture.

sen.j: 1915年（大正4年）11月10日 - 贈正二位。
sen.e: November 10, 1915, given Shonii rank.
On November 10, 1915 he was given the rank of Shonii.
On November 10, 1915 he was given the rank of Shonii (Senior Second Rank).
